NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government ends on 31 December. 
(ii)  In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
This report was prepared by Z. Farhadian-Lorie, Operations Coordination Division,  
South Asia Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Maldives has requested the assistance of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) to develop a new national development plan (the 7th NDP; the Plan) for the period 
2006–2010, and provided ADB with the terms of reference for such assistance. The concept of this 
assistance was supported for funding by the Cooperation Fund in Support of the Formulation and 
Implementation of National Poverty Reduction Strategies (NPRS) at a peer review meeting on 13 
March  2005.  A  Fact-Finding  Mission  (4–11  April  2005)  reached  understandings  with  the 
Government on the long-term goal and objectives of the technical assistance (TA); its scope; 
implementation arrangements; cost and financing arrangements; and the terms of reference for the 
consultants.  The  United  Nations  Development  Programme  (UNDP)  has  expressed  interest  to 
provide support for the TA through the services of experts employed by UNDP and acceptable to 
ADB. The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (Internet edition) on 16 February 2005.  
The TA framework is shown in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Until the end of 2004, the Maldives experienced favorable economic development and 
growth. Real gross domestic product (GDP) growth accelerated to 8.5% in 2003, lifting nominal per 
capita GDP to about $2,509 in that year, the highest in the South Asian region. Growth was led by 
tourism, which expanded by over 15% in 2003 and accounted for about 33% of GDP. The fisheries 
sector, which accounts for about 6% of GDP, is estimated to have grown by about 3% in 2004. 
However, poverty and vulnerability, which are mostly related to remoteness and lack of access to 
public services, remain a serious issue. Maldives remains eligible for concessional assistance from 
ADB’s Asian Development Fund because, notwithstanding its high per capita income, it faces high 
poverty and vulnerability. 
 
3.  In a clear manifestation of its vulnerability, the tsunami of December 2004 will have a major 
impact on the Maldivian economy, much of which will become manifest over the first 6–12 months 
after the event. The joint needs assessment done by the Government, ADB, United Nations (UN), 
and  the  World  Bank  reports  that  the  most  likely  effects  in  2005  will  be  a  severe  economic 
slowdown with low real GDP growth of about 1% of GDP, a doubling of the current account deficit, 
and a significant widening of the fiscal deficit. While it is expected that tourism and fisheries 
activities will likely recover to pre-tsunami capacity toward the latter part of 2005, identifying a more 
expanded role for these sectors in the development of a pro-poor economic growth plan for the 
Maldives remains a challenge.  
4.  The long-term vision for the development of the Maldives is presented in “Vision 2020.” The 
6th National Development Plan (6th NDP; 2001–2005) was designed as a policy- and strategy-
oriented blueprint to steer the development of the first 5 years of Vision 2020 to: 
(i)  Diversify and expand the economy by further developing existing industries and by 
exploring new economic activities, while ensuring the sustainability of physical and 
natural resources; 
(ii)  Increase  the  role  of  private  sector  in  the  development  process,  particularly  in 
expanding the economic base of the country; 
(iii)  Improve the quality and relevance of educational, health, and social services, while 
ensuring  that  the  benefits  of  development  are  shared  equitably  among  the 
population; 
(iv)  Increase the human resource capacity and productivity by providing relevant training 
and employment opportunities; 
(v)  Pursue legislative, regulatory, governance, and administrative reform to facilitate 
rapid economic and social development;

2   
(vi)  Develop  a  sustainable  and  cost-effective  transportation  and  telecommunications 
infrastructure to facilitate economic, social, and regional development; and 
(vii)  Ensure sociopolitical stability and democratic participation of all in the development 
process, while upholding national unity and social cohesiveness based on shared 
social, cultural, and religious values. 
 
5.  The 6th NDP had a collection of appropriate policy statements; however, they were often not 
accompanied  by  realistic  action  plans  for  their  implementation.  Various  stakeholders,  when 
consulted, identified some of the weaknesses of the 6th NDP as: 
 
(i)  The absence of a monitorable framework that could guide the implementation and 
show at each stage the progress achieved.  
(ii)  Lack  of  realistic  strategies  to  implement  the  identified  policies,  and  lack  of 
coordination between various strategies of individual ministries. 
(iii)  The  6th  Plan  was  not  costed  and  did  not  accompany  a  realistic  medium-term 
expenditure framework (MTEF) and a prioritized public investment plan to support it.  
(iv)  Pro-poor  policies  such  as  affordable  housing,  sanitation,  and  water  supply 
management;  employment-generating  economic  growth  activities;  and  skills 
development were not adequately emphasized. 
 
6.  Recognizing these issues, the Government intends to prepare the 7th NDP as a results-
based plan directed to contribute to the achievement of the long-term goals of Vision 2020. The 
goals  of  the  7th  NDP  are:  (i)  reduction  of vulnerability  and  poverty;  (ii)  improving  access  to 
opportunities and services through regional development; (iii) achieving sustainable and equitable 
economic and social development through greater participation of all sectors of the society; and 
(iv) strengthening family values and national unity through investing in social, cultural, and religious 
harmony. It is the intention of the Government to ensure that medium- and long-term priorities are 
clearly defined through a prioritized action plan that includes the sequencing and resourcing of the 
needed actions; that important crosscutting issues such as gender equity drive the design of the 
plan; and that the plan is informed by the Government’s Strategic Economic Plan, the Sectoral 
Master Plans, and the National Recovery and Reconstruction Plan. In this sense, the 7th NDP will 
form the Government’s Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper. As in any results-oriented plan, the 
Government intends to monitor progress made in the implementation of this plan, and report to all 
stakeholders such progress made through a medium-term progress report and a final assessment 
report. 
 
7.  Two sets of factors will affect the Government’s strategy to develop the economy in the 
period covered by the 7th NDP. First, the vulnerability of the country to tsunami and the impact of 
remoteness  on  increasing  poverty  has  necessitated  that  the  Government’s  Population  and 
Development Consolidation Strategy be an important contributor to the future development plans 
of  the  Maldives.  Second,  the  country’s  graduation  from  least-developed  country  status 
necessitates that a transition strategy for the country be developed.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The  impact  sought  by  the  technical  assistance  is  to  contribute  effectively  to  the 
achievement of the goals of the 7th NDP as described in para. 6. The outcome of the TA would be 
a results-based 7th NDP focused on achieving the goals identified in para. 6. The indicators for 
evaluating  ADB’s  success  in  developing  sustainable  capacity  in  the  Government  to  plan, 
implement, and monitor results-based national poverty reduction plan are two: first, the mid-term

3
and final reports on implementation as mentioned in para. 6; second, if, at the completion of the 
TA, the Government is in a position to draft an action plan that 
 
(i)  identifies and ranks actions to be taken during the period covered by the 7th NDP; 
(ii)  aligns external funding resources with the priorities of the 7th NDP; and 
(iii)  sets  priorities  for  the  medium-term  budgetary  framework  in  such  a  way  that  it 
supports the areas of priority in the 7th NDP. 
 
9.  The outputs of the TA are: 
 
(i)  Background study of (a) work done on a medium-term macroeconomic framework; 
(b) the  existing  processes  used  by  the  Government  to  prepare  an  MTEF  with 
coherent  prioritization  of  development  aid  projects  supported  by  appropriate 
budgetary allocations (this study will be done in close coordination with the World 
Bank, which is currently assisting the Government with a TA project focused on 
facilitating the development of an MTEF, improving the process of appraisal and 
selection of capital investment projects, and enhancing expenditure prioritization); 
(c) assessment of existing monitoring and evaluation systems in the public sector, 
including proposals on how to address existing gaps if found; and (d) progress 
made and achievements under the 6th NDP. This output will not require reports, only 
to inform the work on the 7th NDP. 
(ii)  In collaboration with the core ministries, production of medium-term sectoral road 
maps  (accompanied  by  realistic  goals  and  targets,  as  well  as  indicators  of 
monitoring progress toward expected sectoral outcomes) for the development of the 
core sectors. All other ministries will be involved in the process so that these road 
maps will serve as good practice models for the preparation of other sectoral road 
maps by the other ministries. 
(iii)  Provision  of  advice,  needed  background  reports  and  technical  support  to  the 
Government on preparing a results-based national development plan and assisting 
the  Government  in  synthesizing  the  various  inputs  received  from  consultants, 
stakeholders, and other sources into a coherent national plan. 
(iv)  Conducting regional, in-country workshops that would enable ADB, UNDP and the 
Government  to  communicate  with  the  country  stakeholders  (various  ministries, 
private sector businesses, nongovernment organizations, and other stakeholders) 
the objectives and the goal of the process of preparation of the 7th NDP and receive 
input  for  its  design.  Provide  separate  workshops  to  communicate  with  the  line 
ministries the findings of the gender assessment and the MTEF. 
(v)  Initiating gender-sensitive and gender-responsive approaches in all sectors and all 
stages of planning, implementation and monitoring. 
(vi)  Mainstreaming key crosscutting issues in the context of mainstreaming Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs) in the 7th NDP. 
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The activities undertaken under the TA are  designed with the objective of knowledge 
transfer in mind. Therefore, the outputs of the TA will require a series of short discussion notes in 
which issues are brought up and views of relevant stakeholders on best approaches to address the 
issues are sought. Person-to-person or small group discussions will be given preference over an 
impersonal report-producing approach, although the latter is not altogether abandoned as there is 
a need to leave behind a record of understandings reached. The final report of the consultants 
(Appendix 4) is the only formal report to ADB and UNDP.

4   
11.  The TA component on study of existing MTEF processes will assist the Government to 
ensure that the 7th NDP is costed, prioritized, and accompanied by a supportive MTEF. This 
component will link the assistance received so far from the UN agencies, the World Bank, and the 
International Monetary Fund  to the needed requirements for the costing and prioritization of the 
7th NDP and will identify any gaps. This will prompt the Government to seek further assistance 
from various development partners to address these gaps. 
 
12.  The component on study of the macroeconomic framework will study existing processes 
and assistance received from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank for building the 
medium-term macroeconomic framework within the 7th NDP.  
 
13.  The components on assessment of existing monitoring and evaluation systems and the 6th 
NDP,  and  the  assistance  for  producing  sectoral  roadmaps  will  be  done  with  substantial 
involvement of and work done by the staff of ADB and UNDP. These are considered to be areas of 
focus in ADB’s overall agenda to build capacity both at the DMC level and at the corporate level, 
on managing for development results. Therefore, this opportunity will be used to accomplish this 
capacity building at both levels and ensure better transfer of knowledge to the country. 
 
14.  UNDP will not only assist in all activities mentioned above by means of providing the 
services of local consultants acceptable to ADB as needed, but will also undertake its separate 
background studies and advice to the Government in order to assist in initiating gender-sensitive 
and gender-responsive approaches in all sectors and all stages of planning, implementation, and 
monitoring and in mainstreaming key cross-cutting issues. 
 
15.  Furthermore, and also with the aim of better transfer of knowledge, the staff of ADB and the 
UN agencies will participate in making presentations at the consultation workshops and will remain 
engaged in consultations with the Government counterparts to help synthesize the information and 
inputs received toward the production of the 7th NDP itself. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $557,000 equivalent, of which $395,000 is in foreign 
exchange and $162,000 equivalent is in local currency. Of the total cost of the TA, the equivalent 
of $377,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Cooperation Fund for NPRS and administered 
by ADB. As part of its support to the Government for the preparation of the 7th NDP, UNDP will 
provide, on a parallel basis, the equivalent of $100,000 in services of local consultants acceptable 
to ADB to assist in the implementation of the TA, and in conduct of other activities focused on 
initiating  gender-sensitive  and  gender-responsive  approaches  in  all  sectors  and  all  stages  of 
planning,  implementation  and  monitoring  and  on  mainstreaming  key  crosscutting  issues.  The 
Government will provide the equivalent of $80,000 in covering the costs of office accommodation, 
transport, and counterpart staff, as well as other in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and the 
financing program are presented in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA was advertised in ADB Business Opportunities for a 3-month period. The start of 
TA  processing  (fact-finding)  was  delayed  by  several  months  because  of  the  tsunami-related 
emergency activities in the Maldives. However, the final outputs of the project cannot be delayed 
beyond end-2005, as the Government is anxious to have a coherent, medium-term plan in place to 
rule the selection of post-tsunami emergency projects in 2006. Therefore, the TA outputs are 
expected to be produced in a shorter than originally planned period.

5
18.  Given the need for rapid mobilization of the consulting firm, recruitment through direct 
selection is proposed. The particular firm identified for direct selection is appropriately positioned to 
undertake  this  assignment  as  it  has  been  actively  involved  with  results-based  development 
planning in many small-island economies; it has worked on 43 projects supported by various 
multilateral development banks and bilateral development partners in 13 small-island economies. 
In  the  Maldives,  the  firm  has  experience  with  the  environmental  assessment  and  analytical 
overview  of  the  main  natural  resource  base  (fisheries  and  tourism)  and  preparation  of  an 
environmental management plan in the Southern Atolls (project supported by the International 
Fund for Agricultural Development).1 This experience has prepared the selected firm to maintain an 
overview of the possible impact of the Government’s Population and Development Consolidation 
Strategy and the 7th NDP on the fisheries and tourism activities. The outline terms of reference for 
the international consulting team are shown in Appendix 3. 
 
19.  The  Executing  Agency  for  the  TA  will  be  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and  Treasury.  The 
implementing agency will be the Development Planning Section of the Ministry of Planning and 
National Development (MPND). The focal point within the implementing agency will be the Director, 
Development Planning. The MPND will establish a number of committees, each comprising line 
ministries with close mandates, to assume responsibility in the preparation of the 7th NDP. The 
Department of External Resources within the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will assume responsibility 
for  development  partner  coordination,  communications  with  development  partners,  and  for 
involvement of the development partners in the process of preparation of the 7th NDP. 
 
20.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 6 months ending in December 2005. The 
consultants will be assisted by local experts who will be employed by UNDP. The TA will require 
the services of 4 international consultants recruited from a firm for a total of 15 person-months. 
These consultants (whose detailed terms of reference are given in Appendix 3) will include: (i) a 
public finance management specialist with expertise in the budgetary aspects of results-based 
national development planning for 4 person-months; (ii) 2 results management specialist (one with 
emphasis  on  evaluation  and  monitoring,  the  other  on  results-based  national  and  sectoral 
development  planning)  for  a  total  of  8  person-months;  and  (iii)  an  economist  specializing  in 
participatory development aid planning for 3 person-months. The economist will act as the team 
leader to coordinate the activities of the other international consultants, guide the work of local 
experts, and advise the Government as needed. 
 
21.  Activities of the TA will begin with an inception meeting, participated by the ADB, UNDP, 
the  Government,  and  the  consultants,  to  review  and  agree  on  the  goals,  objectives,  guiding 
principles, outputs, and activities of the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $377,000 to the Government of 
the  Maldives  to  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Cooperation  Fund  in  Support  of  the 
Formulation and Implementation of National Poverty Reduction Strategies (NPRS) for Developing 
a Results-Oriented 7th National Development Plan, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Summary of Activities 
 
1.  The public finance specialist will prepare the necessary background studies and report 
on  existing  processes  used  by  the  Government  to  prepare  a  medium-term  expenditure 
framework  (MTEF)  with  coherent  prioritization  of  development  aid  projects  supported  by 
appropriate budgetary allocations. On the basis of the notes and assessments provided by this 
specialist,  and  further  assistance  currently  being  provided  by  the  World  Bank,  the  sector 
ministries  will  be  able  to  identify  all  the  required  projects,  both  for  domestic  and  external 
financing, and develop appropriate project proposals accordingly. He or she will assist ministries 
in developing investment plans that would be needed to achieve the goals of sectoral road 
maps. 
 
2.  The two results management specialists will prepare (i) notes on background study and 
assessment  of  existing  monitoring  and  evaluation  systems  in  the  public  sector,  including 
proposals on how to address existing gaps if found; (ii) assist core ministries—to be jointly 
selected by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Government— to prepare medium-
term sectoral road maps (accompanied by realistic goals and targets, as well as indicators of 
monitoring progress toward expected sectoral outcomes) for the development of their sectors, 
and involve other ministries in this process; (iii) provide a review and assessment of strengths 
and  weaknesses  of  the  6th  National  Development  Plan  (NDP)  and  the  process  of  its 
implementation; and (iv) provide advice and needed background reports to the Government on 
preparing a results-based national development plan and assist the Government in synthesizing 
the various inputs received from consultants, stakeholders, and other sources into a coherent 
national plan. 
 
3.  The  team  leader  will  (i)  coordinate  and  supervise  the  work  of  other  international 
consultants; (ii) jointly with the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), supervise the 
work of local consultants; (iii) make preparations and appropriate presentations for the conduct 
of  regional,  in-country  workshops  that  would  enable  ADB,  UNDP  and  the  Government  to 
communicate  with  the  country  stakeholders  (various  ministries,  private  sector  businesses, 
nongovernment  organizations  and  other  stakeholders)  the  objectives  and  the  goal  of  this 
process and receive input for the design of the 7th NDP; and (iv) liaise with ADB consultants 
who  are  assisting  in  the  implementation  of  the  recently  approved  Tsunami  Emergency 
Assistance Project. 
 
4.  The UNDP-funded local experts will assist the international consultants in their work, 
including for conducting training seminars and participatory workshops. The former will also 
produce the needed studies, reports, and provide advice on mainstreaming of crosscutting 
issues, particularly gender, in the context of mainstreaming the MDGs in the 7th NDP. 
 
5.  All consultants will be guided in their work by the Poverty and Vulnerability Assessments 
(VPAs) done in the Maldives by the Government, with assistance from other development 
partners (latest update in 2004), the VPA3 which will be conducted in mid-2005 with assistance 
from UNDP, and the Joint Needs Assessment Study conducted by all major development 
partners in the aftermath of the tsunami. As part of their work, all consultants will prepare notes 
on areas of need for institutional strengthening and capacity development in the Maldives. 
These notes will form part of the 7th NDP on countrywide, medium-term, holistic planning for 
capacity development in the country. The international consultants will be assisted in their work 
by the expertise provided by a group of local experts funded by UNDP. The exact expertise of

Appendix 3  11 
the local consultants will depend on the needs of the international consultants; therefore, the 
number  of  local  experts  being  engaged  in  this  process  will  vary  at  different  stages  of 
implementation of the technical assistance. 
 
B.  Detailed Terms of Reference 
1.  Public Finance Management Specialist  
6.  The  consultant  with  expertise  in  the  budgetary  aspects  of  results-based  national 
development planning will be employed for 4 person-months (with substantial front-loading of 
activities in the first 3 months of technical assistance implementation, and one final month at the 
time of preparation of final reports) to undertake the following activities: 
 
(i)  Review of the latest public expenditure review by the World Bank; 
(ii)  Review of the degree to which the training workshops and other assistance by 
the World Bank on the MTEF are being implemented; 
(iii)  Conducting a workshop with all line ministries to review the technical details of 
the MTEF and its relevance to the planning procedures.  
(iv)  Discuss with various ministries, prepare a half-day workshop, and build internal 
capacity on the principles of the MTEF in supporting a prioritized development 
plan and the differences with public investment plans; 
(v)  Collaborate with the World Bank and the UNDP consultants working on related 
issues; 
(vi)  Prepare notes on areas of need for further capacity development and institutional 
strengthening. 
 
2.  Two Results Management Specialists 
   
7.  The two consultants with expertise in evaluation and monitoring, and results-based 
development planning will be employed for a total of 8 person-months (spread intermittently 
over a period of 6 months) to undertake the following activities: 
 
(i)  Review current procedures on monitoring of implementation of aid projects.  
(ii)  Prepare needed notes on the gaps in the system, and the best approaches for 
ADB  and  other  development  partners  to  monitor  progress  made  in  the 
implementation  of  their  projects  by  coordinating  with  and  using  in-country 
systems; 
(iii)  Collaborate with the World Bank and the UNDP consultants working on related 
issues; 
(iv)  Prepare notes on areas of need for further capacity development and institutional 
strengthening; 
(v)  Discuss  with  line  ministries  (i)  development  challenges  facing  their  specific 
sectors,  (ii)  barriers  facing  the  ministry  in  addressing  those  challenges, 
(iii) expected outcomes to be observed in the sector within the next 3-5 years 
(based,  mostly,  on  current  development  activities  in  the  sector),  and 
(iv) additional activities needed to achieve expected outcomes and cost of those 
activities; 
(vi)  Provide training and develop understanding within the ministries on how their 
sectors’ needed activities are to be reflected in the MTEF; 
(vii)  Develop a road map for the core sectors with substantial involvement of other 
ministries on the basis of above discussions;

12  Appendix 3 
(viii)  Prepare notes on areas of need for further capacity development and institutional 
strengthening. 
 
3.  Economist/Team Leader  
8.  Specializing in participatory development aid planning the consultant will be employed 
for 3 person-months. The economist will coordinate the activities of the other international 
consultants,  guide  the  work  of  local  experts,  and  advise  the  Government  as  needed. 
Specifically, the consultant will take on the following activities: 
 
(i)  Desk study (and discussions with stakeholders) of strengths and weaknesses of 
the 6th NDP as a policy document and as a development planning document; 
(ii)  Compare the 6th NDP in this respect with the previous NDPs (in which the public 
investment plan was clear, inflexible, and uncoordinated with available external 
resources),  and  prepare  a  note  on  advantages  and  disadvantages  of  each 
method; 
(iii)  Collaborate with the World Bank and the UNDP consultants working on related 
issues; 
(iv)  Prepare notes on areas of need for further capacity development and institutional 
strengthening; 
(v)  Maintain contact with Ministry of Finance and Treasury officials by e-mail and 
through visits to advise them as needed; 
(vi)  Collaborate with the World Bank and the UNDP consultants working on related 
issues; 
(vii)  Prepare notes on areas of need for further capacity development and institutional 
strengthening; 
(viii)  Prepare a plan for the conduct of participatory workshops; identify appropriate 
participants  and  take  action  to  notify  the  target  participants  in  time  for  the 
workshops; 
(ix)  Prepare educational notes intended for capacity development and to encourage 
discussion at the workshops; 
(x)  Ensure that views expressed at the workshops are appropriately recorded and 
transmitted to the relevant public officials; 
(xi)  Develop proposals for future actions with regard to continued involvement of 
stakeholders during plan implementation; 
(xii)  Supervise and coordinate the work being done on gender and development 
issues in the Maldives and provide advice on enhancing gender sensitivity of 
sectoral  policies  and  national  development  planning  and  implementation  to 
ensure that the 7th NDP is prepared as a gender-responsive national plan and 
that key gender issues are addressed.
